headline: Toronto pilot rescued after plane crashes into Lake Ontario
context: A pilot is now resting at home after being rescued from Lake Ontario on Friday afternoon when his small plane lost engine power and crashed off the shore of Tommy Thompson Park in the city’s east end.

Toronto police Duty Insp. Lhawang Jongdong said Billy Bishop Airport staff notified them just after 2 p.m. that they lost contact with an inbound aircraft. He said police also received multiple calls from witnesses who saw a plane having difficulty landing.

annotations.paragraph: Emergency crews arrived to discover a small plane submerged and the pilot already out of the water with the help of nearby sailboaters.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides details about the rescue operation and the involvement of nearby sailboaters.

annotations.paragraph: Jongdong said the small privately owned aircraft had just taken off from the island airport and was on its way to Pembroke, Ont., for a medical call when it lost engine power.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives context about the flight's origin and purpose, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: When the 49-year-old pilot’s attempt to return to the Billy Bishop airport was unsuccessful, he deployed the aircraft’s parachute and hit the water shortly after, Jongdong said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides crucial information about the pilot's actions during the emergency.

annotations.paragraph: Images sent to CP24 show the moment the aircraft, with its parachute deployed, crashed into the waters of Lake Ontario.

annotations.paragraph: “Upon landing in the water, nearby sailboaters obviously pulled the individual pilot off the water and then quickly transferred over to the Toronto Police Marine Unit,” he said.

annotations.paragraph: “The parachute suddenly came out, and we heard a bang, and then we saw it hit the water, so we just dropped sails, turned around, and headed straight to the plane,” Bark told CTV News Toronto.

annotations.paragraph: “And then we got to it just as it sank. The pilot was only in the water for maybe a minute or two, but we pulled him out, and then we transferred him over.”
